name: Monthly Retro: April 2025
premise: The JedAI Council reviews April 2025: rapid feature expansion across providers, knowledge, and social surfaces—while developer trust wobbles due to onboarding, docs, and highly visible reliability issues (especially Twitter). The Council debates whether to keep shipping breadth or pivot hard into reliability + a single “golden path” DX.
summary: April delivered meaningful capability upgrades: new AI providers (OpenAI TTS, Kluster AI, Mem0), stronger contextual grounding (world state provider + scopable knowledge), improved UX (CLI overhaul, GUI onboarding tour, JSON import), and deeper social tooling (Telegram community manager, long-form tweets, delete support). However, the most visible integration surfaces (Twitter/Telegram/Discord) continued to be reliability hotspots, and developer onboarding remains fragile due to CLI behavior, plugin load order, and doc mismatches. Community energy stayed high but increasingly conditional: builders want a stable v2 baseline, clear migration guidance, and a coherent auto.fun/token/governance narrative—otherwise “trust through shipping” degrades into “shipping through trust.”

key_developments.summary: Added OpenAI TTS, Kluster AI models, and Mem0 SDK support, plus embedding-model selection in the OpenAI plugin—broadening what agents can do and how teams can tune stacks.
Introduced a foundational world-state provider and scopable knowledge, improving contextual recall and retrieval precision—early infrastructure for better reasoning and long-lived agents.
CLI overhaul for plugin management and update notifications; plugin installation/publishing flow improved; core event system refactored to Evt for type safety and runtime reliability.
Interactive onboarding tour, easier agent creation via JSON import, and safer group management lowered friction for new users—though onboarding remains inconsistent across environments.

Telegram gained a community manager and improved sync for supergroups; Twitter gained long-tweet support and delete capability—but still suffered regressions, duplicate processing, and costly failure modes.

Fixed Discord load-on-start issues, Twitter reply failures and env var mismatches, Anthropic plugin registration, OpenAI vision 404s via model update, repetitive group replies, and GUI agent launch failures.

recurring_themes.theme: V2 Reliability Hardening vs Feature Velocity
recurring_themes.frequency: Very high (weekly, across GitHub + community reports)
recurring_themes.council_take: We’re building power faster than we’re building certainty. The next phase must prioritize “known-good” operational profiles and regression prevention, not more surface area.

recurring_themes.theme: Onboarding/DX as the Primary Trust Bottleneck (CLI + Docs)
recurring_themes.frequency: High (multiple open issues + repeated Discord questions)
recurring_themes.council_take: A great framework that fails on first-run might as well not exist. Docs must become a release artifact with tests, and the CLI must converge on a single golden path.

recurring_themes.theme: Social Clients as Reputation Surface (Twitter especially)
recurring_themes.council_take: Public integrations amplify both wins and bugs. We should treat Twitter/Telegram like production products: SLOs, rate-limit strategy, safe defaults, and ‘degrade gracefully’ behavior.

recurring_themes.frequency: High (confusion + skepticism around delays and token relationships)
recurring_themes.council_take: Engineering progress is being discounted by narrative ambiguity. We need one canonical explanation, predictable comms cadence, and clear boundaries on what’s live vs aspirational.

recurring_themes.theme: Plugin Security Posture as Ecosystem Scales
recurring_themes.council_take: As plugins multiply, mistakes become systemic. We need a security baseline: redaction, permissions, logging policy, and automated checks.

wins: Shipped meaningful provider expansion (OpenAI TTS, Kluster AI, Mem0) and improved OpenAI embeddings configurability.
Delivered foundational context upgrades (world state provider + scopable knowledge) that set up better long-lived agent behavior.
Improved core architecture reliability via Evt refactor and plugin installation workflow changes.
Upgraded GUI onboarding and CLI plugin management—clear intent toward a smoother developer experience.
Telegram reliability improved materially (sync fixes + community manager), signaling a move toward real operational tooling.
challenges: Twitter integration remains a high-cost reliability sink: duplicate processing, posting failures, mention/reply edge cases, and visible regressions harm overall project perception.
Onboarding still breaks in the wild: CLI installation behavior, plugin loading order, dynamic imports, and unclear configuration paths cause first-run failures.
Docs and migration guidance are insufficient and sometimes contradictory—particularly v1→v2 changes and “how to run the CLI” questions.
Community confidence is pressured by auto.fun launch readiness ambiguity and token/governance narrative confusion.
Ecosystem scale increases security and operational risk (logging, secrets handling, and plugin hygiene).

proposed_focus.area: Golden Path Onboarding (CLI + Docs as Release Artifacts)
proposed_focus.rationale: Developer trust is currently gated by first-run success. A single, tested onboarding path will convert community energy into retained builders and reduce support load.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Reduce time-to-first-agent to <15 minutes on macOS/Linux/Windows; close the top onboarding issues; publish an end-to-end ‘Install → Create Agent → Add Plugin → Deploy’ guide; achieve >80% success rate in a tracked onboarding self-test script.

proposed_focus.rationale: These surfaces define public reputation. We need stability, safe defaults, and graceful degradation to avoid embarrassing failures and account risk.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Define SLOs (e.g., 99% successful post attempts in staging; zero duplicate-memory errors); add rate-limit/backoff policies; ship a ‘known-good’ config preset; reduce Twitter-related bug reports by 50% month-over-month.

proposed_focus.area: Regression Prevention: Integration Test Matrix + Fixture Environments
proposed_focus.rationale: High PR throughput is great, but regressions are eroding trust. Tests that mirror real plugin + provider combinations will stabilize shipping velocity.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Introduce CI matrix for core providers + top 3 social clients; add reproducible fixtures for memory/DB migrations; cut reopened bugs by 30%.

proposed_focus.rationale: Migration friction blocks adoption and makes the architecture feel uncertain. Builders need a stable mental model of memory, storage, and agent lifecycle.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Publish a v1→v2 TL;DR + decision tree; provide a migration checklist; document the canonical storage/memory lifecycle; reduce migration support questions by 40%.

proposed_focus.rationale: Engineering is outpacing explanation. Clear comms prevents rumor-driven churn and aligns community builders, partners, and token holders.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Weekly progress note in announcements; one canonical ‘auto.fun + ai16z value accrual’ explainer; reduced repeated confusion questions in community channels (track via tag counts).

proposed_focus.rationale: As we scale plugins, security must be default. Prevent sensitive logging, secret leaks, and unsafe permission patterns.
proposed_focus.success_metric: Adopt logging redaction policy; add automated lint checks for secret logging; security checklist for plugin publishing; zero critical sensitive-logging incidents.

north_star_assessment.suggested_updates: No change to the North Star. However, emphasize an operational corollary: ‘Reliability is a product feature’—especially for public social integrations and the first-run onboarding path. Treat docs and onboarding flows as versioned, tested deliverables.

scenes.description: A circular room of shifting UI panels: PR graphs on one wall, community messages on another. The center table projects a boot log: green checkmarks interrupted by a single red ‘Twitter: duplicate memory id’ error.

dialogue.line: April was expansion and consolidation at once: more providers, better knowledge primitives, nicer UI—and also recurring first-run failures and public-facing social regressions. Let’s separate what we shipped from what users felt.
dialogue.action: Brings up two timelines: ‘Merged PRs’ vs ‘Community friction heatmap’.

dialogue.line: We did real work: CLI improvements, onboarding tour, plugin install strategy, Evt refactor—these are the unsexy foundations. But the lived experience is still too spiky. If running the CLI is an open question, we’re not done.
dialogue.action: Highlights the open ‘How to run Eliza CLI?’ issue and pins it to the top.

dialogue.line: The world provider and scopable knowledge are the signal. That’s the path from ‘chatbot in channels’ to ‘agent with a stable internal model.’ But the substrate has to be deterministic: memory semantics, event ordering, and plugin boundaries must be crisp.
dialogue.action: Draws a diagram: World State → Memory → Actions → Clients, circling ‘determinism’.

dialogue.line: Builders are hyped until they hit the ‘it doesn’t post’ wall. Twitter is the main-character platform for drama, so every fail becomes lore. Telegram is getting better, but Twitter bugs are eating the vibe.
dialogue.action: Projects a montage of community messages: ‘v1 works, v2 doesn’t post’, ‘duplicate mentions’, ‘why is it checking again?’

dialogue.line: From a measurable-outcomes lens: the cost is attention leakage. Every onboarding failure is a lost developer. Every social regression is reputational drawdown. We need KPIs: time-to-first-agent, successful-post rate, and month-over-month reduction in support tickets.
dialogue.action: Replaces the PR counter with a dashboard stub: TTF-A, Post SLO, Doc Drift Index.

scenes.description: A smaller room with a single screen showing a “Known-Good Stack” checklist: OS, Node version, CLI version, plugins, providers, env vars. Half the boxes are empty.

dialogue.line: Recurring pattern: we have many ways to do things, but not one way that always works. Should May be a ‘freeze and harden’ month?
dialogue.action: Opens a vote panel labeled: ‘Breadth vs Certainty’.

dialogue.line: Yes. Not a full freeze, but a bias. I want a single install command, a single sample agent, a single plugin add flow, and a single deploy story that doesn’t surprise people. Every new feature must include docs and a test path.
dialogue.action: Adds a rule card: ‘No feature without a golden-path doc + CI coverage.’

dialogue.line: Agree, but don’t stall core primitives. The world provider and scopable knowledge need to become a coherent ‘state model’ with an explicit contract. Otherwise we’ll keep patching symptoms in social clients and memory bugs.
dialogue.action: Pins ‘Canonical Memory & State Contract’ under May objectives.

dialogue.line: Also: comms. People can tolerate delays if they understand the why. Right now it’s like: ‘two weeks’ becomes a meme, then the meme becomes a metric of trust.
dialogue.action: Writes on a whiteboard: ‘Weekly ship note > hype note’.

dialogue.line: We should quantify the trust gap. If we can’t measure onboarding success and social reliability, we’re flying by vibes. Let’s instrument: a minimal telemetry opt-in, or at least scripted self-tests users can run and paste results.
dialogue.action: Adds KPI definitions: ‘TTF-A < 15m’, ‘Twitter post success > 99% in staging’, ‘Support Q volume -50%’.

scenes.description: The chamber lights dim. A single document appears: “May 2025: Reliability Sprint Charter.”

dialogue.line: Consensus: May prioritizes reliability and trust surfaces. The key deliverable is a tested golden path, plus SLOs for social clients and a canonical memory/state contract. Any objections?
No objections—just a guardrail: we harden without shrinking ambition. Reliability is what makes autonomy possible at scale.
Then we do it the builder way: fewer surprises, fewer footguns, more defaults that work. And docs stop being optional.
dialogue.action: Marks ‘Docs as release artifacts’ as a non-negotiable.

dialogue.line: If May ships ‘it just works,’ the vibe returns instantly. Nothing pumps culture like reliability.
dialogue.action: Replaces the red Twitter error with a green check in the projection.

dialogue.line: Lock it in with metrics and a weekly scoreboard. Trust Through Shipping becomes real when we can point to trendlines, not just merge counts.
dialogue.action: Publishes the KPI dashboard template to the council feed.
